executive_summary: Amusement parks have experienced notable fluctuations in recent years, greatly influenced by external factors like the global pandemic and the spike in tourism that followed. As travel restrictions lifted, amusement parks saw a surge in visitor numbers from both domestic and international tourists. By 2024, although revenue growth had slowed year-to-year, the industry benefitted from the sustained tourism boom. Despite the surge in attendance, profit has yet to fully recover.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Spike in Tourism Amplified Attendance at Amusement Parks
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Amusement parks maintain high fixed costs, so without an influx of visitors in 2020, parks were operating at a loss. Increased travel after the pandemic's peak benefited amusement parks, as many operate in popular tourist areas with high traffic. When amusement parks reopened, pent-up demand and vaccine availability quickly ushered in a period of solid recovery. By 2021, the removal of travel restrictions bolstered interest in amusement parks as international visitors could come to the US.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Investing in New Attractions Poses a Financial Risk
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Large theme parks periodically invest in costly projects to reinvigorate attendance. Undertaking these new ventures is a significant risk, especially if companies overpromise and underdeliver. In 2022, Disneyworld opened its Star Wars: Galactic Cruiser hotel, a two-day immersive experience that promised guests themed activities, character interactions and role-playing opportunities. Ultimately, the time and money they had to invest in the experience was a big barrier for many consumers and the project failed to generate sufficient demand.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Amusement Parks Focus on Family-Friendly Experiences
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Parents prioritize experiences that suit their entire family's needs, so to compete, some amusement parks have broadened their attractions to better cater to families. Instead of parents watching from the sidelines, families today prefer enjoying rides together. Between full-size and kiddie coasters, there are family coasters designed to accommodate riders of different ages. While these have been a staple at Disney Parks for years, new rides like The Bobcat at Six Flags Great Escape and Pheonix Rising at Busch Gardens Tampa Bay aim to attract families and thrill-seekers alike.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Attendance Remains High Despite Policy Changes
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Raising prices, implementing reservation systems and introducing blackout dates allow amusement parks to control visitor flow and maximize revenue. These operational changes haven't deterred visitation, indicating consumers' willingness to adapt to new policies as long as the park experience remains up to their standards.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Newly Built Attractions Sustain Attendance Over The Next Few Years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In the next few years, amusement parks will reap the benefits of newly opened attractions like Super Mario World at Universal Studios. Anticipation and buzz surrounding upcoming attractions and grand openings will drive pre-sale ticket volumes, guaranteeing a steady flow of visitors.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Widespread Use of New Technology Enhances Immersion
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Amusement parks will increasingly implement the newest available technologies, like VR, AR, advanced robotics and AI, to facilitate immersive experiences. The use of innovative tech will appeal to a new generation of tech-savvy visitors and improve the overall park experience, though overreliance on these features heightens the likelihood of technical glitches or ride shutdowns.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Amusement Parks Turn Their Attention Towards Overseas Customers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The most prominent theme parks have already achieved a stable domestic customer base, so it will be challenging to boost attendance and revenue significantly beyond this point. The biggest corporations will turn more attention to the international tourist market. Amusement parks will increasingly offer attractive packages and discounts to continue stimulating attendance. All-inclusive vacation packages that provide resort accommodations and park admissions are particularly advantageous for the largest theme parks to lock in customers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Price Hikes Hit a Breaking Point
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Large amusement parks have been raising ticket prices yearly to deal with inflation and rising costs, much to the disappointment of their most loyal customers. Even with the introduction of new attractions, the biggest amusement parks risk pricing out lower-income consumers and hitting a profit wall. While demand remains high, constant price hikes may turn amusement parks into a luxury only a few can afford, limiting a park's reach and profitability in the long run.

industry_definition: Amusement parks operate mechanical rides, water rides, games, shows, themed exhibits, refreshment stands and other attractions.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level high - increasing

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: The top five amusement parks, led by Walt Disney, generate the majority of revenue in the US because of their popularity and high traffic. Since they control an enormous market share, it's challenging for new or smaller parks to compete.

Small-scale regional parks operate seasonally and attract only a few hundred thousand visitors yearly. Many small local amusement parks catering to local customers have merged, allowing them to achieve economies of scale and acquire sufficient capital resources.

Amusement parks invest in new attractions to revitalize attendance but must carefully balance costs to ensure long-term success. New worlds and rides can attract visitors but may also create financial risks if not managed effectively.

The increasing use of innovative technologies like VR and AR in amusement parks will revolutionize visitor experiences. Embracing industry innovations will ensure parks stay ahead of the competition and attract a tech-savvy audience.
Six Flags and Cedar Fair are merging, combining their assets under the more prominent Six Flags brand. Cedar Fair shareholders hold a slight majority in the new company.

Disney's strategic focus on branded theme parks has driven growth despite setbacks, like the closure of the Star Wars: Galactic Cruiser. Acquisitions like Fox have positioned the company for long-term dominance.

Regulation among amusement parks is mainly related to public safety, including regular maintenance and inspection of rides. The CPSC regulates amusement parks in the US, enforcing safety standards, investigating accidents and issuing recalls for non-compliant equipment.

Although amusement parks do not receive direct or special assistance from the federal government, they benefit from general tourism-related promotions. Tourism promotion grants provide vital financial support for amusement parks' marketing initiatives.

Depreciation costs and wages significantly impact amusement park operations. Investing in new rides and facility upgrades is crucial to attracting visitors, while managing labor costs through part-time staff is key to controlling operating expenses.

Amusement parks lost profit due to fixed costs and attendance fluctuations. Profit has recovered slowly, but has not yet reached pre-pandemic levels, highlighting the ongoing challenge of financial stability.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Amusement parks cater primarily to US residents, with the most significant demographic groups being individuals between the ages of 25 and 54. These age groups represent those most likely to have children, increasing their ability to organize travel and leisure plans toward amusement and theme parks.

Amusement parks cater primarily to US residents, with the most significant demographic groups being individuals between the ages of 25 and 54. These age groups represent those most likely to have children, increasing their ability to organize travel and leisure plans toward amusement and theme parks.
The most prominent industry consumer market is individuals aged 35 to 44, as these parents likely have children of the ideal age for amusement park visits.

Amusement parks cater primarily to US residents, with the most significant demographic groups being individuals between the ages of 25 and 54. These age groups represent those most likely to have children, increasing their ability to organize travel and leisure plans toward amusement and theme parks.
Individuals aged 55 and older represent retired consumers who often carry more disposable income and available leisure time.

Visitors worldwide will attend famous destinations or tourist parks like Disney World and Universal Studios instead of small-scale regional amusement parks catering to local, domestic consumers. International travel has spiked since the end of the pandemic, encouraging individuals who postponed travel plans to rebook.

products_and_services.product_description: Amusement parks derive most revenue from entrance ticket sales. These can include single-day, multi-day or annual park tickets. Amusement parks may also charge customers to enjoy additional activities like rides, games, shows and experiences.
Most visitors spend all day at an amusement park, so theme parks generate significant revenue from selling food and beverages, including restaurants, vendors, snack bars and alcoholic beverages.

Amusement parks sell merchandise to promote their branded rides and attractions, including memorabilia, apparel, accessories, books, toys and packaged snacks. Larger parks benefit from licensing popular brands and characters.
Miscellaneous offerings that complement the visitor experience.

tier_1_suppliers: Food Service Contractors in the US
Musical Groups & Artists in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Wine & Spirits Wholesaling in the US
Surveying & Mapping Services in the US
Soft Drink, Baked Goods & Other Grocery Wholesaling in the US
Construction & Mining Equipment Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Consumer spending levels directly affect travel rates and the amount of money consumers are willing to spend on leisure activities like amusement parks.

business_locations.location_description: Beautiful weather and tourism makes Florida and California ideal locations for amusement parks. The Walt Disney Company and Universal Parks & Resorts operate the biggest parks in the country in these states.
Amusement parks are dispersed according to regional tourism levels and an area's share of the US population.

The Southwest enjoys a warm, sunny climate that allows amusement parks to operate throughout the year and attracts visitors throughout the seasons. Rapid population growth in the Southwest provides a large and increasing customer base, supporting the establishment and success of numerous amusement parks. Texas has become the hotbed of new, small-scale establishments.
The Walt Disney Company and Universal Parks & Resorts operate some of the biggest parks in California.
Amusement parks are dispersed according to regional tourism levels and an area's share of the US population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) regulates the amusement park industry in the US by enforcing safety standards for amusement rides and attractions. They conduct inspections, investigate accidents and issue recalls or safety alerts for non-compliant equipment. The CPSC works with state and local authorities to ensure compliance.

Under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), amusement parks are required to provide accessible pathways, facilities and attractions for guests with disabilities. Ensuring compliance with ADA guidelines not only enhances visitor inclusivity but also widens the potential customer base, making parks more enjoyable and accommodating for everyone, regardless of their physical limitations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The amusement park industry is in a mature life cycle stage.
The industry has very high revenue volatility.
The industry receives low and steady levels of assistance.
There is high and increasing competition in the industry.

basis_points.basis_description: Established theme parks like Disney World and Universal Parks & Resorts use their intellectual properties to build strong brand reputations and customer loyalty, creating a barrier for new entrants.
Constructing worthwhile rides and attractions involves an enormous initial investment, necessitating extensive access to capital or external funding.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top 5 parks account for majority revenue
concentration_points.concentration_description: The five largest parks, led by Walt Disney, account for the majority of amusement park revenue in the US.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Remaining enterprises are small local parks
concentration_points.concentration_description: Many of the remaining enterprises are small, local amusement parks with only one venue that operate seasonally and attract far fewer visitors than the giants.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation Costs are a Significant Annual Expense That Affects Many Purchasing Decisions
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Amusement parks have relatively high capital costs, as rides and attractions require frequent updates to attract new and returning visitors. Depreciation costs have grown over the last few years.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages are a Major Cost for Amusement Parks
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Operating an amusement park is labor-intensive in all areas, including administration, ticket-selling, food and merchandise sales and operation and maintenance of rides, displays and equipment.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Constructing worthwhile rides and attractions involves an enormous initial investment, necessitating extensive access to capital or external funding. Significant upfront capital is needed not only to enter but to succeed in the industry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CONSUMER SPENDING TRENDS INFLUENCE DEMAND FOR AMUSEMENT PARKS
volatility_points.volatility_description: During periods of economic growth, consumer spending expands as rising disposable income allows more consumers to spend their discretionary funds. During periods of economic decline, demand growth is tapered as consumers cut back on discretionary costs in favor of personal savings and debt obligations.

volatility_points.volatility_title: DOMESTIC AND INTERNATIONAL AIR TRAVEL TRENDS DRIVE REVENUE
volatility_points.volatility_description: Major parks like Disney World and Universal Studios are located in popular vacation destinations. Often, families regularly plan amusement park trips as annual getaways from work and school. This dynamic is present among international tourists since large-scale parks can typically market domestic attractions in foreign markets.

Many amusement parks are subject to extreme revenue volatility throughout the calendar year, mainly due to seasonal factors, such as holidays and weather. Amusement parks commonly earn close to two-thirds of annual revenue between Memorial Day and Labor Day, syncing with warmer months and school vacations.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: More amusement parks will use intellectual properties (IPs), such as film franchises and TV series, to create new games and merchandise to attract new and returning customers. Third-party movie producers can license to those who do not own IPs.
Many amusement parks are integrating Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR) technologies to create more immersive and interactive attractions.

FAQs.question: Does seasonality affect sales for the products and services your company offers?
FAQs.answer: Seasonality generally affects sales for the services of the Amusement Parks industries. For example, the summer is especially lucrative for operators, as children are on break from school.

FAQs.question: How do domestic and international tourism indicators impact overall company sales?
FAQs.answer: Domestic and international tourism indicators impact sales in the industry because the largest operators generate revenue from parks in specific locations of the US. The more people travel for vacation, the more likely an amusement park will be one of their destinations.

FAQs.question: How do you manage capital expenses on infrastructure to maximize profit?
FAQs.answer: Parks will strategically invest in new rides and attractions that are expected to draw increased visitation. For example, Universal opened a Wizarding World of Harry Potter attraction in Orlando.

FAQs.question: How does your company use location to add value and offer unique products and services to your consumers?
FAQs.answer: Operators in the industry often use the locations of their parks to offer diversified services for their customers, including hotels, restaurants, and other forms of entertainment.

FAQs.question: Has your company integrated web and mobile reservation and appointment systems to improve consumer accessibility?
FAQs.answer: Amusement parks maintain strong connections with consumers through the use of the internet. Consumers can buy admission tickets online through websites and order tickets via telephone.

FAQs.question: Has your company updated facilities in order to enhance the consumer experience?
FAQs.answer: Operators constantly update their amusement parks to have the best systems in place, including surveillance monitoring, cleaner restrooms and new rides and attractions.

FAQs.question: Do you offer membership agreements, tickets or passes that may be subject to state or federal regulation?
FAQs.answer: Many parks offer seasonal or annual passes for consumers, with state and federal regulations regarding the purchaser's age. Oftentimes, young children must be accompanied by a parent or guardian at all times when in an amusement park.

FAQs.question: How are you ensuring compliance with safety regulations and requirements?
FAQs.answer: Safety is paramount in an amusement park environment. Therefore, understanding the steps taken to ensure compliance with safety regulations is vital for operational success.

FAQs.question: Do you develop off-season demand through alternative products and services to maintain a steady cashflow during slower seasons?
FAQs.answer: Some amusement parks, like Six Flags Great Adventure, will offer alternative events that coincide with holidays, like Halloween. Many will host parades to garner steady cashflow.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margin compare to industry-average figures?
FAQs.answer: Company-specific profit above or below industry average figures generally implies pricing power or weakness.

FAQs.question: How do you retain skilled laborers? Do you offer a variety of incentives to increase your workforce?
FAQs.answer: Because of seasonal variations in the number of visitors, it is important for operators to have access to a large pool of multiskilled and part-time workers. Maintaining seasonal and temporary workers is vital to sustaining operations as it makes industry cost structures much more flexible.

FAQs.question: Are you currently located near your key markets? How can you advertise to markets that are further away? Have you explored strategic merger or acquisition activity?
FAQs.answer: Amusement parks should choose locations near areas with significant populations and domestic and international visitors. Strategic merger or acquisition activity can help penetrate previously untapped geographic markets.

FAQs.question: What kind of promotions do you offer to stay ahead of your competition? What measures do you take to monitor your nearby competition?
FAQs.answer: Parks should closely monitor the nearby competition in terms of admission prices and investment; if possible, they should consider developing a joint visitor ticket promotion to attract and hold visitors in the area longer.

FAQs.question: How do you contend with such a volatile demographic? How will you respond to a possible decline?
FAQs.answer: Families with adolescent children and teenagers make up the primary consumer market for the industry. An increase in the number of adolescent children will indicate a rise in demand for industry services.

FAQs.question: How does your company adapt to decreased consumer spending?
FAQs.answer: Consumer spending levels have a direct effect on travel demand and the amount of money consumers are willing to spend on leisure activities. Declining consumer spending negatively affects demand.

FAQs.question: What marketing strategies have you put in place to bring in incoming visitors? Do you offer domestic travel and accommodations packages?
FAQs.answer: Any economic, social, political or environmental factor that affects consumer sentiment or the ability to travel domestically will also affect industry performance. Industry demand falters when domestic travel slows.
